title: What happens to hoa fees after foreclosure?
question: Had a condo in Los Angeles, could not afford to pay HOA fees, or the mortgage, for the last 12 month I was living there. Finally, the bank foreclosed in September 2012. HOA never filed any liens for the fees. Now, HOA is suing me for the unpaid fees up until the date of foreclosure. Can they do that?
answers:
Unlike delinquent property taxes which stay with the real property and its current owner, delinquent HOA fees can follow a person after he or she no longer owns the real property. HOA dues incurred at a certain time are owed by whoever owned the real property at that certain time. Thus, if an owner does not pay the HOA fees for six months, and then the real property is "lost to the bank," six months of HOA dues are owed by that owner who lost the home. The bank will owe HOA dues starting from the moment of foreclosure. The HOA can then attempt to collect the delinquent six months from the previous owner by whatever legal means are available to collect unpaid debts.

- Paul

Yes, this was an agreement that you signed when you purchased this condo. I agree that talking to an experienced lawyer would be good.

You are personally responsible for those fees for the period of time you owned the property. This is true whether or not liens were filed against the property or the property was lost due to foreclosure of a senior DOT.

I suggest you contact a lawyer to determine if you have any defenses to the lawsuit. You may also wish to consult bankruptcy counsel if the claim and/or your other debts are substantial as the claim would likely be dischargeable in BK.
